But Irish sources said the government would reject any approach from May for a bilateral side deal, calling the idea a “non-starter”. Sources in Dublin said the EU was “very clear” the withdrawal agreement could not be reopened unless May changed her red lines. The Irish foreign minister, Simon Coveney, said: “I can assure you that the Irish government’s commitment to the entire withdrawal agreement is absolute, including the backstop to ensure, no matter what, an open border between Ireland and Northern Ireland, and the Good Friday Agreement, are protected.” A source said: “The solidarity in the EU is complete there, as Donald Tusk and Jean-Claude Juncker made clear; they are waiting to see what Theresa May’s plan B is. From our perspective, a bilateral deal is just not a credible proposal.”

webTitle: Stefanos Tsitsipas beats Roger Federer: Australian Open 2019 – as it happened

fields.headline: Stefanos Tsitsipas beats Roger Federer: Australian Open 2019 – as it happened
fields.standfirst:
• No 14 seed beats defending champion 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 7-6
  • Barty fights back to beat Sharapova, Kerber crashes out
fields.trailText: Stefanos Tsitsipas battled his way to a shock victory over Roger Federer to make it to the quarter finals
fields.body:
1.14pm GMT

Here’s our match report:

Related: Stefanos Tsitsipas stuns Roger Federer in four-set Australian Open thriller

12.51pm GMT

Here are some post-match quotes from Roger Federer:

“I have massive regrets tonight. I felt like I have to win the second set. I don’t care how I do it, but I have to do it. Cost me the game tonight.”

On John McEnroe’s on-court remarks that the result marked a changing of the guard, Federer replied: “He’s in front of the mic a lot. He’s always going to say stuff. I love John. I’ve heard that story the last 10 years. From that standpoint, nothing new there.

“About Stefanos, I think he’s definitely done a really nice job now the last year and a half. Before that, too, obviously. But beating Novak in Toronto, the likes of Anderson and Zverev, now me here.

“That’s what you need to do to get to the next level. He’s doing that. It’s really nice for him. I see him definitely being high up in the game for a long time. That was a good night for him tonight.”

12.36pm GMT

Kevin Mitchell’s report will arrive shortly, but here’s a snap report from PA:

Roger Federer’s chances of winning a third consecutive Australian Open title were ended as 20-year-old Stefanos Tsitsipas came of age on Rod Laver Arena.

The Greek, who was not born when Federer made his professional debut, has rapidly established himself as one of the most exciting up-and-coming talents in the game and backed it up spectacularly with a 6-7 (11) 7-6 (3) 7-5 7-6 (5) victory to move through to a first grand slam quarter-final.

Federer had not lost a match at Melbourne Park since a semi-final defeat to Novak Djokovic in 2016 but his often brilliant forehand was wayward, especially at the big moments, and he failed to take four set points in the second set that might well have changed the outcome.

The 37-year-old must have glimpsed something of his younger self in his opponent, from the flowing single-handed backhand, the willingness to charge the net, and the confidence to believe he could beat his childhood idol, just as Federer did to Pete Sampras at Wimbledon in 2001.

Tsitsipas said: “Roger is a legend of the sport, (I have) so much respect for him. He showed such good tennis over the years. I’ve been idolising him since the age of six. It was a dream come true just being on Rod Laver facing him. Winning at the end, I cannot describe it.”

12.11pm GMT

Right ... that was an interesting start to everyone’s Sunday. I am off to find a massive coffee and some lunch. You should all do the same.

Have we witnessed a star born in Melbourne? Only time will tell but I am looking forward to finding out.

Until we meet again.

12.10pm GMT

Tsitsipas takes the applause of the crowd and treats them to his sweatbands.

He departs the court with a the customary signing of the TV camera.

12.07pm GMT

“I haven’t seen such a loud crowd in my life,” Tsitsipas adds.

He wasn’t saying that when they were randomly shouting “Out!”.

12.07pm GMT

Tsitsipas says: “There is nothing I can compare it to, I am the happiest man on earth right now. I can’t describe it.

“Roger is a legend of our sport, so much respect for him. He showed such good tennis over the years, I’ve been analysing him since the age of since. It was a dream just being on Rod Laver playing against him and to win it at the end, I cannot describe it.”

12.03pm GMT

CRASH, BANG, WALLOP WHAT A TENNIS MATCH!

Tsitsipas goes back to sit down and take it what he has just achieved. Federer had won the two previous Australian Opens and few would have been surprised by a third. The Greek has his head in his hands, almost in shock.

12.01pm GMT

TSITSIPAS WINS THE MATCH!

Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 7-6 Federer

TIE-BREAK! Tsitsipas starts with an ace. Federer then sends a forehand down the line a touch long to put him on the back foot. A failed lob from the Greek brings it back to 2-1. WHAT A SHOT FROM FEDERER! After an impressive rally he produces a stunning forehand across the court to make it 2-2. Ooooof! As responses go, an ace down the middle from Tsitsipas is not a bad one. The crowd then erupts when the Greek sends a shot into the net for 3-3. Great athleticism from Tsitsipas gets him to a drop shot from Fed but he then fires it long. Federer then whacks a backhand well wide to make it 4-4. This is pretty tense, as Fed proves with a weak backhand into the net for no reason. Fed smashes an ace down the middle ... but there is a challenge, which is erroneous. A line judge has made the latest “Out” call off all time. It is out! And now this is match point!!! Tsitsipas serves ... and he Fed sends the ball into the net!! GAME, SET AND MATCH!!!

Updated at 12.19pm GMT

11.53am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 6-6 Federer*

Federer is ferocious from the off in this game but he gets a bit excited and sends a wayward forehand wide. Some stunning work at the net from Fed sees him volley a few potential winners but Tsitsipas is equal to them but is eventually worn down by the onslaught. Tsitsipas repeatedly looks like he wants to challenge a call but he has no reviews left. He sends two long for Fed to win. Another tie-break.

11.48am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 6-5 Federer

“Oh man!” is the cry from Federer after he smashes the ball into the net with a backhand. He doesn’t waste breath next time around as he watches an ace fly by and the Greek takes the game to love. Will he break to win?

11.46am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 5-5 Federer*

A break here would see Tsitsipas caused a right old upset in Melbourne. Surely Federer won’t lose the match when serving. His opening serve would indicate I am right and he quickly moves into a 30-0 lead but a fierce backhand gets Tsitsipas back into it but not for long as Federer thwacks a forehand well out of reach and he holds.

Updated at 11.46am GMT

11.43am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 5-4 Federer

A passing backhand from Federer gets the crowd up on their feet. It was a lovely shot to be fair. Federer really needed that. Tsitsipas, laden with his rich leg cream, does not seem to be moving as quickly as previously as Federer makes it 30-30 but some renewed vigour helps to home the game.

11.39am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 4-4 Federer*

The medical assistance and delay has seen the crown turn against Tsitsipas with a bit of booing. Federer tests out his physicality with a wide serve which he cannot reach. The game continues along similar lines as Federer holds with minimal fuss.

11.37am GMT

Tsitsipas has pointed to an arm issue and is now just having some cream rubbed into his legs. It just seems like cramp at the moment. Take on more fluids, mate.

11.35am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 4-3 Federer

Here comes the trainer!! Maybe Tsitsipas just wants to allowed the crowd a little break from this intense. The Greek shows no sign of weakness as he steams in a 40-0 lead but he offers Federer a glimpse of hope as the Swiss wins two consecutive points but an ace takes the game.

11.32am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 3-3 Federer*

Tsitsipas has called for the trainer due to a leg issue. Federer might be very excited about the prospect his opponent is weakened. He certainly is taking advantage of any impediment in this game, winning it to love after pushing the Greek around the court.

Updated at 12.06pm GMT

11.30am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 3-2 Federer

Federer brings it back to 30-30 with some great athleticism which helped him return a shot with a mishit, much to Tsitsipas’ surprise, resulting in the Greek send a shot well wide. He is not too worried by this and takes the game. As a side note, Tsitsipas has no challenges remaining.

James emails (from Melbourne): “I’m at the match, one of the best matches I’ve ever seen live. Torn between my love for Federer and my excitement for how good Tsitsipas is at 20 years old.

“I think I’ve come to the conclusion that the best ending to this match is Federer to somehow find another level in these two sets and pull out the win. Reminding everyone he is still the master but that Tsitsipas will be entertaining us for many years to come.”

I thank you for distracting yourself from this match to email me.

11.26am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 2-2 Federer*

Federer is put on the back foot, literally and metaphorically, by Tsitsipas as the Greek takes the first point but this is followed by an ace. Federer is now battling here; he is taken to 30-30 and then produces a incredible volley at the net to put himself in control but he wastes it and is taken to Deuce. Possibly out frustration he smashes a serve and then a volley to take the game.

11.20am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 2-1 Federer

Top rallying culminates in Tsitsipas volleying the ball into space to win the first point and he rightly celebrates with a fist pump and he comfortably holds his serve.

11.18am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 1-1 Federer*

The fans are getting behind Federer now. Everyone loves Fed. He repays their love with a dropped volley over the net to take the first point of the game. Things go quickly downhill for Fed who goes 15-30 down following a woeful volley at the net. The match has seen some utterly woeful reviews, the latest coming from Tsitsipas who things his mishit forehand was in, it was not. Federer takes the game despite the best efforts of the Greek who returns a drop shot but sends it just long.

Updated at 12.07pm GMT

11.14am GMT

Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 1-0 Federer

Now he has the advantage, Tsitsipas looks more confident, serving his way to the first game of the fourth set without giving Federer a sniff thanks to three consecutive aces.

11.11am GMT

TSITSIPAS WINS THE THIRD SET!

Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5 Federer*

WE HAVE A BREAK!!!

Tsitsipas smashes a shot straight at Federer who just can’t react quick enough to get a volley back over the net. Fed then sends one long to make it 15-30. If anyone is tiring in this match, it is Federer. Two set points for the Greek ... and he breaks Federer who smashes on into the net!!

Updated at 11.12am GMT

11.05am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 6-5 Federer

No fuss from Tsitsipas as he does not offer Federer a chance on his serve. Are we heading for another tie-break?

11.03am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 5-5 Federer*

Tsitsipas is happy to chase whatever Federer sends his way and it does not seem to be tiring him out but it is currently a wasted occupation as Fed holds to love.

11.00am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 5-4 Federer

Those failed break points are quickly forgotten by Tsitsipas as breezes into a 30-0 lead on his serve and an ace wins the game for him.

Updated at 11.08am GMT

10.57am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 4-4 Federer*

An opening for Tsitsipas as he goes into a 0-30 lead on Federer’s serve and a cross-court forearm earns two break points. The Swiss comes back strong to take the game to Deuce. They were Tsitsipas’ first break points of the match, which shows how good Fed has been. Speaking of which, Fed holds.

If anyone is in the vicinity of Guardian HQ, could they please bring supplies? Some coffee, chocolate biscuits and wine. I think this could be a long one.

10.52am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 4-3 Federer

A superb rally starts the game, ending with a smashing volley from Federer after Tsitsipas just about returned a drop shot. Federer moves the Greek around the court, leading to two break points. Surely this is the time he will finally break his younger opponent ... but he mishits a forearm which almost ended up in Sydney. We are at Deuce and Federer has now failed to take 12 break points. Is that a record against Fed? Tsitsipas is lured into the net and then plays a passing shot down the line to earn advantage. Stunning from Federer to stay in the game after a rally saw both men moving all over the court but culminating in a great backhand down the line from the Swiss to take us back to Deuce. Tsitsipas earns advantage and shouts “Let’s go!” which does to win the game.

10.44am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 3-3 Federer*

Fed completely messes up a volley. A sign of the pressure? He rectifies the situation to take the game with a perfect volley at the second time of asking.

10.41am GMT

Kath is now trying to make me remember a second thing to learn one thing. I was up very early for this, Kath, you can’t expect too much of me.

10.40am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 3-2 Federer

Federer offers a hand of apology after he clips the net and kills the ball dead to make it 15:15, much to Tsitsipas’ chagrin. The Greek does not flinch and makes up for it with a cracking inside-out forearm. Still no breaks in this match as Tsitsipas sends an ace down the middle.

10.37am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 2-2 Federer*

A slow rally ends with Federer hitting the net but he doesn’t mess about on his next serve to level the score. He goes ahead but then completely miscues a forehand which goes well wide and he is eventually taken to Deuce, a rare bit of pressure on the Federer serve. Did I say pressure? Oh he eases through Deuce with no fuss.

10.32am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 2-1 Federer

It’s 9.30pm in Melbourne and there is another game on after this, which might finish around noon tomorrow at this rate. Fed comes in behind a second serve but needlessly whacks it straight into the net when he must have been eyeing a winner. Tsitsipas volleys his way to winning the game, he his improving as the game goes on.

10.29am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 1-1 Federer*

Intense stuff form Federer as he ensures Tsitsipas feels the heat in Melbourne as he takes the game with little fuss.

10.26am GMT

Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 1-0 Federer

Here we go again! It is pretty draining watching this match, so God knows how the lads on the court are feeling. A bad backhand from Tsitsipas needlessly sends a shot wide under little pressure but he makes amends to level things up at 30-30 and then takes the game.

There are some very lively ducks or something in the background in Melbourne which is adding a weird background noise.

10.20am GMT

TSITSIPAS WINS THE SECOND SET!

Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6 Federer

TIE BREAK! Federer starts it off by woefully miscueing a shot into the stands pretty much. Not how you want to start on your serve. Tsitsipas on the other hand smashes two aces, the second just about kissing the line, as proved by Hawkeye. Fed gets back into it as the Greek’s inside-out forearm heads out to make it 3-1. The Swiss then offers up the look of a man about to kill after a bad call from the umpire results in the point being replayed. Much to his relief, he wins that one. Federer levels things up with a sublime backhand down the line. Wonderful. With the pressure back on Tsitsipas he holds his nerve in a rally, ending with Fed finding the net and then he makes it 5-3 with a passing forearm. He then keeps his calm to let a volley pass him, in the knowledge it was heading just out. Tsitsipas serves for the set ... and wins it!

Updated at 10.32am GMT

10.12am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 6-6 Federer

Tsitsipas serves to stay in the set and does so with aplomb as takes the game to love. No break point chances for Fed here. Another tie-break.

10.11am GMT

Abhijato says: “I wanted to comment on the camera angles used in this Open. They often cut away to the view from just behind the players, which gives us a more intimate feel of the way the game is being played. The overhead shot often seems to make the ball easier to see, but the use of the court cameras should be more encouraged - the awkward bounce and height from the best shots is captured through these frames. If the broadcasters stream these games online, maybe there could be a stream permanently from these cameras, accompanied by nothing but the sounds of the game with optional commentary? I would pay to watch them any day.”

I have found some of the TV directing very strange. Keep it simple, lads.

10.09am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 5-6 Federer*

A lesser man might have collapsed under the pressure from Federer but Tsitsipas is giving everything to stay in this game, so much so his shoelace has broken. A quick change of footwear means we are back playing but it is business as usual for Federer as he takes the game.

10.05am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 5-5 Federer

After playing Come On Eileen, we are back to the real business of tennis. There is some creaking in Tsitsipas’ game, he has put in a lot of effort to be fair, and after a stunning rally he hits a backhand long giving a break point. The Greek ensures we go to Deuce with a big serve. Federer gets another chance of a break but a serve down the middle does the job for Tsitsipas to make it eight break points Fed has failed to take in the match. He gets the chance of a ninth and misses out again with a poor shot from the baseline. A tenth comes immediately thanks to a cracking shot across court but it is not taken as Tsitsipas volleys a winner. Great endeavour from the Greek, who then gets his own chance to win the game which he does take.

9.55am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 4-5 Federer*

Bish, bash, bosh. Federer wins the game to love. Great serving from him today.

9.54am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 4-4 Federer

Federer lures Tsitsipas to then net then flashes a forehand past him. Federer does similar again but this time beats him with cunning rather than power to make it 0-30. The Greek recovers with a couple of heaving shots to level things up and head to Deuce thanks to a stunning backhand down the line from Federer following one of the match’s better rallies. Ooooof! Deuce #3 sees Tsitsipas volley his way to advantage but he then gets unlucky on the next point as a Federer shot clips the net and he just gets it back over but the Swiss smashes a winner. Deuce #5 gives Federer break point but his backhand, when he has a chance of winning the game, goes very long. Don’t worry, there is always Deuce #6 to bring this to a conclusion and it does as Federer sends the ball into the net. Still no breaks of serve.

9.42am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 3-4 Federer*

Federer has won 10 points in a row on serve and takes the game. Federer is looking the more likely winner at the moment, I would say.

9.40am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 3-3 Federer

Will I learn how to spell Tsitsipas off the top of my head before this match finishes? No probably not.

The last break points on serve were in the opening game of the match but we have another! Federer brings Tsitsipas to the net and then smashes a forehand straight back past him. The Greek takes us to Deuce despite looking trouble during the crucial rally but it is Fed who overhits a forehand. A review is called for from Tsitsipas and he is proven right that Federer’s shot was just out. But we are back to Deuce. The Greek then sends a backhand long and Fed has another chance to break his younger opponent but his return smashes into the net. Federer looks in a good position to break Tsitsipas but stopped when chasing down a drop shot even though he could have got there, even Fed himself looks confused. Serve is held by the Greek after three break points. Lively.

Updated at 9.41am GMT

9.29am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 2-3 Federer*

Federer takes the games to love. Easy peasy.

Tony emails: “Re the morons in the crowd shouting out during rallies - surely the stewards, or indeed other members of the crowd, can identify the loud-mouthed miscreants and have them removed? Seeing a few idiots frogmarched out of the stands might discourage the others?

“PS what a terrific match this is!”

It is a great match and to we should ensure it continues in this way by having the idiots removed quickly and in as embarrassing a fashion as possible.

9.27am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 2-2 Federer

This is not going to be a quick match, is it? Both players are looking in stupendous form and know the other’s weakness, which is making it compelling viewing. The Greek ensures that no service games have been lost as he takes the game 40-15, concluding with a dramatic volley.

9.23am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 1-2 Federer*

We might be here for quite a while here. Federer is looking more and more clinical as the match progresses but Tsitsipas shows what he is made of with a great backhand return to a serve and then Federer messes up a drop shot to make it 30-30. Fed takes the game.

Updated at 9.23am GMT

9.21am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 1-1 Federer

Tsitsipas tries to regain his composure after a whirlwind first game of the second set as he serves himself back into the game, making it 30-0 with a great backhand volley to keep things interesting and he also takes the game to love. Lovely stuff.

9.19am GMT

Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 0-1 Federer*

The Greek had a bit of a chat with the umpire there as it is the second time someone has shouted out from the crowd with an erroneous call of “Out!”. The umpire has warned the crowd but they do not seem intelligent enough to understand it. Federer takes the game to love.

9.15am GMT

FEDERER WINS FIRST SET

First set: Tsitsipas 6-7 Federer

Tsitsipas starts the tie-break by taking the first two points to put the pressure back on Federer. A bad backhand from the Greek misses its mark and levels it at 2-2 but he follows that up with an ace. It’s 3-3 thanks to a great volley from Federer forcing his opponent to send the ball long in response. Federer shouts “Come on!” when going 4-3 up to show how tough it is out there and there is a similar shout from Tsitsipas when he immediately levels things. Plenty of quality and commitment in the tie-break. Federer sends a forehand long to make it 5-5 but then Tsitsipas can’t return the following serve. But some positive tennis from the Greek allows him to volley a winner from the net to level things up. Federer miscues a forehand to give his opponent Set Point but there is no chance he is giving him a chance with a superb serve which kisses the line. Set Point is then with Federer but he fails to take it and then smashes a forehand into the net for no reason from the baseline, leaving Tsitsipas a chance to take the set but we all know that is not happening on Federer’s serve as he volleys a winner and then a drop shot leaves him on the brink but he sends his shot well wide to make it 10-10. It goes to 11-11 as the Greek hits the net with a backhand. It’s Set Point once again for Fed as he doesn’t mess about with a forehand. Federer then wins the first set after some tosser in the crowd shouts “Out!”. Tsitsipas is not happy but those are the breaks when idiots are around.

8.59am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas 6-6 Federer*

Federer has been put under plenty of pressure and a drop shot from Tsitsipas forces him to send his response into the net. The Swiss does not worry and wins the next two points thanks to some great first serving. Here comes a tie-break.

8.56am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas* 6-5 Federer

Tsitsipas loses his first point on his serve for a while as he fails to execute a backhand, which hits the net. He regains his composure and sends some powerful shots Federer’s way which he just can’t fire back and the Greek takes the game with a great backhand volley at the net, made all the better as he was falling over at the time.

8.53am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas 5-5 Federer*

Needing to win the game to stay in the set brings out the best of Federer as he goes 30-0 up but then Tsitsipas shows his worth with a great backhand down the line to get back into the game. A stunning rally results in Federer smashing a winner which flicks the line, before the Swiss takes the game.

8.49am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas* 5-4 Federer

Federer is getting moved around the court here by Tsitsipas and he does not like it. His forehand is coming under pressure and even his backhand is being undermined. Tsitsipas wins the game and has now won the last 13 points on his serve.

8.47am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas 4-4 Federer*

New balls in Melbourne result in Federer misjudging their bounce and firing one well off court. He produces his first ace in response but then his fifth forced error of the game lets his opponent back in and Tsitsipas takes us to Deuce with a stunning backhand out of Federer’s reach across court from the baseline. Federer gets into the net to earn advantage and then takes the game.

8.42am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas* 4-3 Federer

Tsitsipas is targeting the forehand and it is working for him. Not to mention he stunning ace down the middle to make it 40-0. He then finishes off by putting plenty of spin on a shot and Federer can only smash it into the net. We’ve got a game on here.

8.40am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas 3-3 Federer*

There is a challenge from Tsitipas on a Federer serve to get the game going. The Greek has a chat with the umpire and in the end loses his challenge. Federer makes Tsitipas move around the court, almost playing with him but the 20-year-old gets his own back with a stunning forehand down the line to make it 40-30 and then Federer miscues one for Deuce. The Swiss regains his composure to take the game.

8.35am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas* 3-2 Federer

No messing about from Tsitsipas in response as he puts the pressure back on his more esteemed colleague forcing a couple of errors and then taking the game to love with a lovely volley at the net which Federer cannot get to in time.

8.33am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas 2-2 Federer*

A decent backhand rally gets Federer’s second service game underway. Both men have superb backhands like they’re using wands. The Swiss wins that challenge and then shows Tsitsipas that he cannot be lobbed as the Greek sends a lob long. In the end Federer takes the game to love to show he is not messing about. He has only conceded a point in his opening two service games.

Updated at 8.34am GMT

8.29am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas* 2-1 Federer

The Greek seems to be targeting Federer’s forehand as he eases through his second service game by winning with minimal fuss on this occasion. All those nerves are now being lost by Tsitsipas.

8.27am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas 1-1 Federer*

Federer’s first service game is a bit of a calmer affair as the Swiss smashes some clinical shots to ensure his opponent knows how ferocious this game is going to be. It was certainly quicker than the first game of the match.

8.24am GMT

First set: Tsitsipas* 1-0 Federer (*denotes server):

Tsitsipas gets us going and puts Federer under plenty of early pressure but Federer is unflustered by a couple of big serves. Tsitipas is nervous and gets a time warning at break point but recovers to take Federer to Deuce. Federer almost takes advantage with a superb shot across the court but it is inches out but an error from the Greek levels things up. Tsitsipas double faults because he fails to take his serve in time and then sends it long without option of a second one. On the upside he then has an out call overturned for a serve as it just kissed the line. This is a fascinating opening game, as Federer takes the game back to Deuce with some superb play at the net which Tsitipas cannot cope with. In the end Tsitipas holds the game. More of this, please.

8.14am GMT

Barty got the better of Sharapova earlier ...

Related: Australian Open: Barty overcomes first-set loss to see off Sharapova

8.10am GMT

They are both out on court and are knocking up a bit. Some lovely early backhands to get you in the mood.

8.03am GMT

Preamble

Good morning!

Stefanos Tsitsipas comes into this game hoping that self-belief might be enough to see off Roger Federer but that might a bit of a stretch. The Greek is the 14th seed in Melbourne and is certainly capable of a shock but Federer is still looking superb at the ripe old age of 37 and no one would be surprised if he were to win his seventh Australian Open this time around.

Tsitsipas has a potentially wonderful career ahead of him and a win today would certainly be a turning point.

Could be a cracking game in store!
fields.bodyText: Here’s our match report: Here are some post-match quotes from Roger Federer: “I have massive regrets tonight. I felt like I have to win the second set. I don’t care how I do it, but I have to do it. Cost me the game tonight.” On John McEnroe’s on-court remarks that the result marked a changing of the guard, Federer replied: “He’s in front of the mic a lot. He’s always going to say stuff. I love John. I’ve heard that story the last 10 years. From that standpoint, nothing new there. “About Stefanos, I think he’s definitely done a really nice job now the last year and a half. Before that, too, obviously. But beating Novak in Toronto, the likes of Anderson and Zverev, now me here. “That’s what you need to do to get to the next level. He’s doing that. It’s really nice for him. I see him definitely being high up in the game for a long time. That was a good night for him tonight.” Kevin Mitchell’s report will arrive shortly, but here’s a snap report from PA: Roger Federer’s chances of winning a third consecutive Australian Open title were ended as 20-year-old Stefanos Tsitsipas came of age on Rod Laver Arena. The Greek, who was not born when Federer made his professional debut, has rapidly established himself as one of the most exciting up-and-coming talents in the game and backed it up spectacularly with a 6-7 (11) 7-6 (3) 7-5 7-6 (5) victory to move through to a first grand slam quarter-final. Federer had not lost a match at Melbourne Park since a semi-final defeat to Novak Djokovic in 2016 but his often brilliant forehand was wayward, especially at the big moments, and he failed to take four set points in the second set that might well have changed the outcome. The 37-year-old must have glimpsed something of his younger self in his opponent, from the flowing single-handed backhand, the willingness to charge the net, and the confidence to believe he could beat his childhood idol, just as Federer did to Pete Sampras at Wimbledon in 2001. Tsitsipas said: “Roger is a legend of the sport, (I have) so much respect for him. He showed such good tennis over the years. I’ve been idolising him since the age of six. It was a dream come true just being on Rod Laver facing him. Winning at the end, I cannot describe it.” Right ... that was an interesting start to everyone’s Sunday. I am off to find a massive coffee and some lunch. You should all do the same. Have we witnessed a star born in Melbourne? Only time will tell but I am looking forward to finding out. Until we meet again. Tsitsipas takes the applause of the crowd and treats them to his sweatbands. He departs the court with a the customary signing of the TV camera. “I haven’t seen such a loud crowd in my life,” Tsitsipas adds. He wasn’t saying that when they were randomly shouting “Out!”. Tsitsipas says: “There is nothing I can compare it to, I am the happiest man on earth right now. I can’t describe it. “Roger is a legend of our sport, so much respect for him. He showed such good tennis over the years, I’ve been analysing him since the age of since. It was a dream just being on Rod Laver playing against him and to win it at the end, I cannot describe it.” CRASH, BANG, WALLOP WHAT A TENNIS MATCH! Tsitsipas goes back to sit down and take it what he has just achieved. Federer had won the two previous Australian Opens and few would have been surprised by a third. The Greek has his head in his hands, almost in shock. Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 7-6 Federer TIE-BREAK! Tsitsipas starts with an ace. Federer then sends a forehand down the line a touch long to put him on the back foot. A failed lob from the Greek brings it back to 2-1. WHAT A SHOT FROM FEDERER! After an impressive rally he produces a stunning forehand across the court to make it 2-2. Ooooof! As responses go, an ace down the middle from Tsitsipas is not a bad one. The crowd then erupts when the Greek sends a shot into the net for 3-3. Great athleticism from Tsitsipas gets him to a drop shot from Fed but he then fires it long. Federer then whacks a backhand well wide to make it 4-4. This is pretty tense, as Fed proves with a weak backhand into the net for no reason. Fed smashes an ace down the middle ... but there is a challenge, which is erroneous. A line judge has made the latest “Out” call off all time. It is out! And now this is match point!!! Tsitsipas serves ... and he Fed sends the ball into the net!! GAME, SET AND MATCH!!! Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 6-6 Federer* Federer is ferocious from the off in this game but he gets a bit excited and sends a wayward forehand wide. Some stunning work at the net from Fed sees him volley a few potential winners but Tsitsipas is equal to them but is eventually worn down by the onslaught. Tsitsipas repeatedly looks like he wants to challenge a call but he has no reviews left. He sends two long for Fed to win. Another tie-break. Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 6-5 Federer “Oh man!” is the cry from Federer after he smashes the ball into the net with a backhand. He doesn’t waste breath next time around as he watches an ace fly by and the Greek takes the game to love. Will he break to win? Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 5-5 Federer* A break here would see Tsitsipas caused a right old upset in Melbourne. Surely Federer won’t lose the match when serving. His opening serve would indicate I am right and he quickly moves into a 30-0 lead but a fierce backhand gets Tsitsipas back into it but not for long as Federer thwacks a forehand well out of reach and he holds. Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 5-4 Federer A passing backhand from Federer gets the crowd up on their feet. It was a lovely shot to be fair. Federer really needed that. Tsitsipas, laden with his rich leg cream, does not seem to be moving as quickly as previously as Federer makes it 30-30 but some renewed vigour helps to home the game. Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 4-4 Federer* The medical assistance and delay has seen the crown turn against Tsitsipas with a bit of booing. Federer tests out his physicality with a wide serve which he cannot reach. The game continues along similar lines as Federer holds with minimal fuss. Tsitsipas has pointed to an arm issue and is now just having some cream rubbed into his legs. It just seems like cramp at the moment. Take on more fluids, mate. Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 4-3 Federer Here comes the trainer!! Maybe Tsitsipas just wants to allowed the crowd a little break from this intense. The Greek shows no sign of weakness as he steams in a 40-0 lead but he offers Federer a glimpse of hope as the Swiss wins two consecutive points but an ace takes the game. Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 3-3 Federer* Tsitsipas has called for the trainer due to a leg issue. Federer might be very excited about the prospect his opponent is weakened. He certainly is taking advantage of any impediment in this game, winning it to love after pushing the Greek around the court. Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 3-2 Federer Federer brings it back to 30-30 with some great athleticism which helped him return a shot with a mishit, much to Tsitsipas’ surprise, resulting in the Greek send a shot well wide. He is not too worried by this and takes the game. As a side note, Tsitsipas has no challenges remaining. James emails (from Melbourne): “I’m at the match, one of the best matches I’ve ever seen live. Torn between my love for Federer and my excitement for how good Tsitsipas is at 20 years old. “I think I’ve come to the conclusion that the best ending to this match is Federer to somehow find another level in these two sets and pull out the win. Reminding everyone he is still the master but that Tsitsipas will be entertaining us for many years to come.” I thank you for distracting yourself from this match to email me. Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 2-2 Federer* Federer is put on the back foot, literally and metaphorically, by Tsitsipas as the Greek takes the first point but this is followed by an ace. Federer is now battling here; he is taken to 30-30 and then produces a incredible volley at the net to put himself in control but he wastes it and is taken to Deuce. Possibly out frustration he smashes a serve and then a volley to take the game. Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 2-1 Federer Top rallying culminates in Tsitsipas volleying the ball into space to win the first point and he rightly celebrates with a fist pump and he comfortably holds his serve. Fourth set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 1-1 Federer* The fans are getting behind Federer now. Everyone loves Fed. He repays their love with a dropped volley over the net to take the first point of the game. Things go quickly downhill for Fed who goes 15-30 down following a woeful volley at the net. The match has seen some utterly woeful reviews, the latest coming from Tsitsipas who things his mishit forehand was in, it was not. Federer takes the game despite the best efforts of the Greek who returns a drop shot but sends it just long. Fourth set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 7-5, 1-0 Federer Now he has the advantage, Tsitsipas looks more confident, serving his way to the first game of the fourth set without giving Federer a sniff thanks to three consecutive aces. Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 7-5 Federer* WE HAVE A BREAK!!! Tsitsipas smashes a shot straight at Federer who just can’t react quick enough to get a volley back over the net. Fed then sends one long to make it 15-30. If anyone is tiring in this match, it is Federer. Two set points for the Greek ... and he breaks Federer who smashes on into the net!! Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 6-5 Federer No fuss from Tsitsipas as he does not offer Federer a chance on his serve. Are we heading for another tie-break? Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 5-5 Federer* Tsitsipas is happy to chase whatever Federer sends his way and it does not seem to be tiring him out but it is currently a wasted occupation as Fed holds to love. Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 5-4 Federer Those failed break points are quickly forgotten by Tsitsipas as breezes into a 30-0 lead on his serve and an ace wins the game for him. Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 4-4 Federer* An opening for Tsitsipas as he goes into a 0-30 lead on Federer’s serve and a cross-court forearm earns two break points. The Swiss comes back strong to take the game to Deuce. They were Tsitsipas’ first break points of the match, which shows how good Fed has been. Speaking of which, Fed holds. If anyone is in the vicinity of Guardian HQ, could they please bring supplies? Some coffee, chocolate biscuits and wine. I think this could be a long one. Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 4-3 Federer A superb rally starts the game, ending with a smashing volley from Federer after Tsitsipas just about returned a drop shot. Federer moves the Greek around the court, leading to two break points. Surely this is the time he will finally break his younger opponent ... but he mishits a forearm which almost ended up in Sydney. We are at Deuce and Federer has now failed to take 12 break points. Is that a record against Fed? Tsitsipas is lured into the net and then plays a passing shot down the line to earn advantage. Stunning from Federer to stay in the game after a rally saw both men moving all over the court but culminating in a great backhand down the line from the Swiss to take us back to Deuce. Tsitsipas earns advantage and shouts “Let’s go!” which does to win the game. Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 3-3 Federer* Fed completely messes up a volley. A sign of the pressure? He rectifies the situation to take the game with a perfect volley at the second time of asking. Kath is now trying to make me remember a second thing to learn one thing. I was up very early for this, Kath, you can’t expect too much of me. Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 3-2 Federer Federer offers a hand of apology after he clips the net and kills the ball dead to make it 15:15, much to Tsitsipas’ chagrin. The Greek does not flinch and makes up for it with a cracking inside-out forearm. Still no breaks in this match as Tsitsipas sends an ace down the middle. Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 2-2 Federer* A slow rally ends with Federer hitting the net but he doesn’t mess about on his next serve to level the score. He goes ahead but then completely miscues a forehand which goes well wide and he is eventually taken to Deuce, a rare bit of pressure on the Federer serve. Did I say pressure? Oh he eases through Deuce with no fuss. Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 2-1 Federer It’s 9.30pm in Melbourne and there is another game on after this, which might finish around noon tomorrow at this rate. Fed comes in behind a second serve but needlessly whacks it straight into the net when he must have been eyeing a winner. Tsitsipas volleys his way to winning the game, he his improving as the game goes on. Third set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6, 1-1 Federer* Intense stuff form Federer as he ensures Tsitsipas feels the heat in Melbourne as he takes the game with little fuss. Third set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 7-6, 1-0 Federer Here we go again! It is pretty draining watching this match, so God knows how the lads on the court are feeling. A bad backhand from Tsitsipas needlessly sends a shot wide under little pressure but he makes amends to level things up at 30-30 and then takes the game. There are some very lively ducks or something in the background in Melbourne which is adding a weird background noise. Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 7-6 Federer TIE BREAK! Federer starts it off by woefully miscueing a shot into the stands pretty much. Not how you want to start on your serve. Tsitsipas on the other hand smashes two aces, the second just about kissing the line, as proved by Hawkeye. Fed gets back into it as the Greek’s inside-out forearm heads out to make it 3-1. The Swiss then offers up the look of a man about to kill after a bad call from the umpire results in the point being replayed. Much to his relief, he wins that one. Federer levels things up with a sublime backhand down the line. Wonderful. With the pressure back on Tsitsipas he holds his nerve in a rally, ending with Fed finding the net and then he makes it 5-3 with a passing forearm. He then keeps his calm to let a volley pass him, in the knowledge it was heading just out. Tsitsipas serves for the set ... and wins it! Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 6-6 Federer Tsitsipas serves to stay in the set and does so with aplomb as takes the game to love. No break point chances for Fed here. Another tie-break. Abhijato says: “I wanted to comment on the camera angles used in this Open. They often cut away to the view from just behind the players, which gives us a more intimate feel of the way the game is being played. The overhead shot often seems to make the ball easier to see, but the use of the court cameras should be more encouraged - the awkward bounce and height from the best shots is captured through these frames. If the broadcasters stream these games online, maybe there could be a stream permanently from these cameras, accompanied by nothing but the sounds of the game with optional commentary? I would pay to watch them any day.” I have found some of the TV directing very strange. Keep it simple, lads. Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 5-6 Federer* A lesser man might have collapsed under the pressure from Federer but Tsitsipas is giving everything to stay in this game, so much so his shoelace has broken. A quick change of footwear means we are back playing but it is business as usual for Federer as he takes the game. Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 5-5 Federer After playing Come On Eileen, we are back to the real business of tennis. There is some creaking in Tsitsipas’ game, he has put in a lot of effort to be fair, and after a stunning rally he hits a backhand long giving a break point. The Greek ensures we go to Deuce with a big serve. Federer gets another chance of a break but a serve down the middle does the job for Tsitsipas to make it eight break points Fed has failed to take in the match. He gets the chance of a ninth and misses out again with a poor shot from the baseline. A tenth comes immediately thanks to a cracking shot across court but it is not taken as Tsitsipas volleys a winner. Great endeavour from the Greek, who then gets his own chance to win the game which he does take. Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 4-5 Federer* Bish, bash, bosh. Federer wins the game to love. Great serving from him today. Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 4-4 Federer Federer lures Tsitsipas to then net then flashes a forehand past him. Federer does similar again but this time beats him with cunning rather than power to make it 0-30. The Greek recovers with a couple of heaving shots to level things up and head to Deuce thanks to a stunning backhand down the line from Federer following one of the match’s better rallies. Ooooof! Deuce #3 sees Tsitsipas volley his way to advantage but he then gets unlucky on the next point as a Federer shot clips the net and he just gets it back over but the Swiss smashes a winner. Deuce #5 gives Federer break point but his backhand, when he has a chance of winning the game, goes very long. Don’t worry, there is always Deuce #6 to bring this to a conclusion and it does as Federer sends the ball into the net. Still no breaks of serve. Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 3-4 Federer* Federer has won 10 points in a row on serve and takes the game. Federer is looking the more likely winner at the moment, I would say. Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 3-3 Federer Will I learn how to spell Tsitsipas off the top of my head before this match finishes? No probably not. The last break points on serve were in the opening game of the match but we have another! Federer brings Tsitsipas to the net and then smashes a forehand straight back past him. The Greek takes us to Deuce despite looking trouble during the crucial rally but it is Fed who overhits a forehand. A review is called for from Tsitsipas and he is proven right that Federer’s shot was just out. But we are back to Deuce. The Greek then sends a backhand long and Fed has another chance to break his younger opponent but his return smashes into the net. Federer looks in a good position to break Tsitsipas but stopped when chasing down a drop shot even though he could have got there, even Fed himself looks confused. Serve is held by the Greek after three break points. Lively. Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 2-3 Federer* Federer takes the games to love. Easy peasy. Tony emails: “Re the morons in the crowd shouting out during rallies - surely the stewards, or indeed other members of the crowd, can identify the loud-mouthed miscreants and have them removed? Seeing a few idiots frogmarched out of the stands might discourage the others? “PS what a terrific match this is!” It is a great match and to we should ensure it continues in this way by having the idiots removed quickly and in as embarrassing a fashion as possible. Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 2-2 Federer This is not going to be a quick match, is it? Both players are looking in stupendous form and know the other’s weakness, which is making it compelling viewing. The Greek ensures that no service games have been lost as he takes the game 40-15, concluding with a dramatic volley. Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 1-2 Federer* We might be here for quite a while here. Federer is looking more and more clinical as the match progresses but Tsitsipas shows what he is made of with a great backhand return to a serve and then Federer messes up a drop shot to make it 30-30. Fed takes the game. Second set: Tsitsipas* 6-7, 1-1 Federer Tsitsipas tries to regain his composure after a whirlwind first game of the second set as he serves himself back into the game, making it 30-0 with a great backhand volley to keep things interesting and he also takes the game to love. Lovely stuff. Second set: Tsitsipas 6-7, 0-1 Federer* The Greek had a bit of a chat with the umpire there as it is the second time someone has shouted out from the crowd with an erroneous call of “Out!”. The umpire has warned the crowd but they do not seem intelligent enough to understand it. Federer takes the game to love. First set: Tsitsipas 6-7 Federer Tsitsipas starts the tie-break by taking the first two points to put the pressure back on Federer. A bad backhand from the Greek misses its mark and levels it at 2-2 but he follows that up with an ace. It’s 3-3 thanks to a great volley from Federer forcing his opponent to send the ball long in response. Federer shouts “Come on!” when going 4-3 up to show how tough it is out there and there is a similar shout from Tsitsipas when he immediately levels things. Plenty of quality and commitment in the tie-break. Federer sends a forehand long to make it 5-5 but then Tsitsipas can’t return the following serve. But some positive tennis from the Greek allows him to volley a winner from the net to level things up. Federer miscues a forehand to give his opponent Set Point but there is no chance he is giving him a chance with a superb serve which kisses the line. Set Point is then with Federer but he fails to take it and then smashes a forehand into the net for no reason from the baseline, leaving Tsitsipas a chance to take the set but we all know that is not happening on Federer’s serve as he volleys a winner and then a drop shot leaves him on the brink but he sends his shot well wide to make it 10-10. It goes to 11-11 as the Greek hits the net with a backhand. It’s Set Point once again for Fed as he doesn’t mess about with a forehand. Federer then wins the first set after some tosser in the crowd shouts “Out!”. Tsitsipas is not happy but those are the breaks when idiots are around. First set: Tsitsipas 6-6 Federer* Federer has been put under plenty of pressure and a drop shot from Tsitsipas forces him to send his response into the net. The Swiss does not worry and wins the next two points thanks to some great first serving. Here comes a tie-break. First set: Tsitsipas* 6-5 Federer Tsitsipas loses his first point on his serve for a while as he fails to execute a backhand, which hits the net. He regains his composure and sends some powerful shots Federer’s way which he just can’t fire back and the Greek takes the game with a great backhand volley at the net, made all the better as he was falling over at the time. First set: Tsitsipas 5-5 Federer* Needing to win the game to stay in the set brings out the best of Federer as he goes 30-0 up but then Tsitsipas shows his worth with a great backhand down the line to get back into the game. A stunning rally results in Federer smashing a winner which flicks the line, before the Swiss takes the game. First set: Tsitsipas* 5-4 Federer Federer is getting moved around the court here by Tsitsipas and he does not like it. His forehand is coming under pressure and even his backhand is being undermined. Tsitsipas wins the game and has now won the last 13 points on his serve. First set: Tsitsipas 4-4 Federer* New balls in Melbourne result in Federer misjudging their bounce and firing one well off court. He produces his first ace in response but then his fifth forced error of the game lets his opponent back in and Tsitsipas takes us to Deuce with a stunning backhand out of Federer’s reach across court from the baseline. Federer gets into the net to earn advantage and then takes the game. First set: Tsitsipas* 4-3 Federer Tsitsipas is targeting the forehand and it is working for him. Not to mention he stunning ace down the middle to make it 40-0. He then finishes off by putting plenty of spin on a shot and Federer can only smash it into the net. We’ve got a game on here. First set: Tsitsipas 3-3 Federer* There is a challenge from Tsitipas on a Federer serve to get the game going. The Greek has a chat with the umpire and in the end loses his challenge. Federer makes Tsitipas move around the court, almost playing with him but the 20-year-old gets his own back with a stunning forehand down the line to make it 40-30 and then Federer miscues one for Deuce. The Swiss regains his composure to take the game. First set: Tsitsipas* 3-2 Federer No messing about from Tsitsipas in response as he puts the pressure back on his more esteemed colleague forcing a couple of errors and then taking the game to love with a lovely volley at the net which Federer cannot get to in time. First set: Tsitsipas 2-2 Federer* A decent backhand rally gets Federer’s second service game underway. Both men have superb backhands like they’re using wands. The Swiss wins that challenge and then shows Tsitsipas that he cannot be lobbed as the Greek sends a lob long. In the end Federer takes the game to love to show he is not messing about. He has only conceded a point in his opening two service games. First set: Tsitsipas* 2-1 Federer The Greek seems to be targeting Federer’s forehand as he eases through his second service game by winning with minimal fuss on this occasion. All those nerves are now being lost by Tsitsipas. First set: Tsitsipas 1-1 Federer* Federer’s first service game is a bit of a calmer affair as the Swiss smashes some clinical shots to ensure his opponent knows how ferocious this game is going to be. It was certainly quicker than the first game of the match. First set: Tsitsipas* 1-0 Federer (*denotes server): Tsitsipas gets us going and puts Federer under plenty of early pressure but Federer is unflustered by a couple of big serves. Tsitipas is nervous and gets a time warning at break point but recovers to take Federer to Deuce. Federer almost takes advantage with a superb shot across the court but it is inches out but an error from the Greek levels things up. Tsitsipas double faults because he fails to take his serve in time and then sends it long without option of a second one. On the upside he then has an out call overturned for a serve as it just kissed the line. This is a fascinating opening game, as Federer takes the game back to Deuce with some superb play at the net which Tsitipas cannot cope with. In the end Tsitipas holds the game. More of this, please. Barty got the better of Sharapova earlier ... They are both out on court and are knocking up a bit. Some lovely early backhands to get you in the mood. Good morning! Stefanos Tsitsipas comes into this game hoping that self-belief might be enough to see off Roger Federer but that might a bit of a stretch. The Greek is the 14th seed in Melbourne and is certainly capable of a shock but Federer is still looking superb at the ripe old age of 37 and no one would be surprised if he were to win his seventh Australian Open this time around. Tsitsipas has a potentially wonderful career ahead of him and a win today would certainly be a turning point. Could be a cracking game in store!

webTitle: Saturday Night Live: Rachel Brosnahan and the less than marvelous misses

fields.headline: Saturday Night Live: Rachel Brosnahan and the less than marvelous misses
fields.standfirst: The Maisel star only made it to the center of a sketch at the very end – and promptly showed what might have been
fields.trailText: The Maisel star only made it to the center of a sketch at the very end – and promptly showed what might have been
fields.body:
The first Saturday Night Live of 2019 kicks off with Deal or No Deal: Government Shutdown Edition. Replacement host Steve Harvey (Kenan Thompson) welcomes Donald Trump (Alec Baldwin), who attempts to make a deal with Congress to end the shutdown and get funding for his border wall.

Related: The tragic legacy of John Belushi: ‘He could have done anything'

Nancy Pelosi (Kate McKinnon) is one of the briefcase holders. “Drunk on [her] own power”, she needles Trump with abandon. The pair bicker “like two grandparents fighting over a thermostat”. The president eventually moves on to spineless Chuck Schumer, who’s willing to concede for “$15 plus a pastrami on rye”.

The rest of the sketch is a rundown of this week’s headlines – Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s ascendance, Corey Booker’s naked presidential ambitions, Cardi B’s tirade, “hamberders”. It appears 2019 will be more of the same when it comes to the show’s lazy political content, as this was yet another cold open that seemed to equate satire with basic reference.

Emmy award-winner and The Marvelous Mrs Maisel star Rachel Brosnahan fulfills her New Year’s resolution by hosting for the first time. She leads several castmembers in a singalong about how 2019 will be the year of having fun, only to continually “pump the breaks” every time they recall one of the myriad disasters in which the world is mired: the shutdown, the LA teachers strike, turmoil in Europe, the Russian drug “krokodile” (the show’s a bit late with that reference). It’s another case of commentary by way of reference, but at least there’s a structural point to it here.

In what seems to have become tradition, the first sketch, Earthquake News Report, is a simple vehicle for crass but clever double entendre. A news team interviews the survivors of a massive quake, all of who were visiting the Seattle change-of-name office at the time. This pitiable collection includes Donald McRonald, Mark Peanus, Lisa Simpson, Bill Cosby, Ty Neadick, Todd Kobell, Ivan Jerganov, Pete Ophelia, Allan “A” Hitler, Holden Tudiks, and Dr Donna Diddaadog.

Next is a clever commercial parody for Leave Me Alun – a portable urn women can use as a “conversation prophylactic” when men attempt unwanted small talk.

Millennial Millions is a gameshow in which millennials attempt to win basic entitlements like healthcare, social security and debt relief. To hold on to their winnings they must endure the ramblings of their idiotic baby boomer parents without losing their cool. Given the younger generation’s inability to accept “anything that challenges [their] worldview”, this proves easier said than done.

The Raunchiest Mrs Rita is a spinoff of The Marvelous Mrs Maisel, starring Leslie Jones as a foul-mouthed ‘60’s cleaning lady who becomes a superstar comedian in the Def Comedy Jam mode. It’s a clever idea that never really leans into its premise, instead coming off as a lazy excuse to have Brosnahan play her breakout role.

Rockers Greta Van Fleet make their SNL debut, performing You’re the One. Then Weekend Update returns and immediately goes back over ground covered in the cold open: the shutdown, Trump’s “hamburger orgy” and bad-faith negotiation tactics, Ocasio-Cortez’s prominence, Schumer’s cravenness. Colin Jost gets the biggest reaction – half laughter/half groans – with a cringe-worthy R Kelly joke.

Presidential hopeful Elizabeth Warren (McKinnon) is Update’s first guest. She talks about her progressive vision, defends herself against sexist criticism – “Am I likeable? Probably not. But neither is a prostate exam, but you need one or you’ll die” – and acknowledges the short-sightedness of her public DNA test: “Who knew race science wasn’t a good PR strategy?” She ends with a cutting appeal to the country’s worst instincts: “America, you will do everything you possibly can to not vote for a woman president. All I’m asking is that you let me be that woman.”

She’s followed by Update’s de facto third host, Pete Davidson, as himself. He’s who’s brought along a friend and mentor, comedian John Mulaney. They briefly discuss Davidson’s public suicide threat from late last year (he says he’s doing better), before giving a snarky rundown of Clint Eastwood’s weirder-than-expected new movie, The Mule, which, among other things, sees the nearly 90-year-old actor-director engaging in multiple threesomes.

Related: Saturday Night Live skit sends up Theresa May's Brexit woes

Kool-Aid is a toothless parody of Gillette’s controversial “We Believe: The Best Men Can Be” ad. The Gillette story is loaded with subtext rife for comic savaging: commercial manipulation of social justice issues, corporate hypocrisy, performative wokeness, childishness of rightwing backlash. But the show’s writers ignore all that, content with reminding audiences of the obnoxious, wall-smashing antics of the product’s famous mascot.

Greta Van Fleet perform Black Smoke Rising. Given the episode’s recurring theme of baby boomers vs millennials, it’s fitting that the musical guest should be a young band so indebted to Led Zeppelin.

Finally, we get a new installment of Barbie Instagram. Exasperated Mattel execs Travis (Thompson) and Diedre (Cecily Strong) meet their buffoonish marketing team, a group of dunces as oblivious to their product as they are to social media. Brosnahan is the standout as an especially deranged team member who seems to be using Ken and Barbie’s relationship to work out her own disturbing drama. It’s unfortunate that Brosnahan gets to be the center of a sketch only at the very end of the episode.

While this wasn’t a particularly poor showing, it did mostly waste its comedically inclined host and the political content remained depressingly weak. That feels particularly egregious, given everything it has to work with.

webTitle: How malbec scaled the heights

fields.headline: How malbec scaled the heights
fields.standfirst: The rise of the grape that’s at its best on mountain slopes is an epic tale
fields.trailText: The rise of the grape that’s at its best on mountain slopes is an epic tale
fields.body:
The story of malbec is an epic that begins in south-west France, and takes in vine plagues, medieval trade wars and a long struggle for recognition. Then it switches gears into a classic new-world rags-to-riches tale that concludes with the variety finally securing global fame from a lofty perch in vineyards in the Andes in western Argentina.

Until relatively recently I wouldn’t have said the wines made from this itinerant grape variety were quite as exciting as their origin story. The initial wave of malbecs to emerge from Argentina were certainly appealing. They had an innate plum and black cherry fleshiness, a mouthfilling plumpness and generosity that made them very easy to drink.

But they lacked that extra something – complexity, longevity, depth – that would have placed them among the world’s best wines. There was an interchangeability to the rows of malbec lined up in the supermarkets. More expensive bottles tended to over-reach, ladling on the oak and over-ripening the fruit.

Argentinian malbec remains the king of soft, reliable and affordable reds – which is why it is such a success in the UK. What’s changed in the past five years is the wine-making has become more sensitive, playing up what I think are the variety’s claims to greatness: an aromatic prettiness featuring floral and herbal as well as berry-fruited notes, combined with that fleshy mid-palate and a pinot-noir-like silkiness.

This is the result of the efforts that leading producers – from big names such as Catena to rising stars such as the Michelini Brothers – have put in to understanding the effects of the combination of soil, exposition and different degrees of altitude on these lofty vineyards. This is at its most advanced in what is the country’s most exciting region: the Uco valley in Mendoza, where sub-zones such as Gualtallary, Paraje Altamira and Vista Flores are creating an Andean answer to Burgundy’s famously filigree patchwork of vineyards. But you can see it, too, further north in the even more extreme altitudes of Salta province, and on the lower-lying terrain of Patagonia.

There has been similar progress, albeit on a smaller scale, back in the vineyards that follow the bends of the River Lot around Cahors in south-west France, while Chile is increasingly getting the hang of the grape. The wilderness years are over, then, but the malbec epic has only really just begun.

Six of the best malbecs

Château du Cèdre Camille Malbec, France 2017 (from £9.85, josephbarneswines.com; bottleapostle.com)
One of Cahors’ best and longest-established producers, Château du Cèdre here shows off malbec in its most fragrantly attractive, pretty and succulent mode, with an unoaked style that positively sings with pure cherry, plum and violets.

Co-op Irresistible Bío Bío Malbec, Bío Bío, Chile 2016 (£7.95, The Co-op)
Malbec came to Chile before Argentina, but has only recently started to make its presence felt on the western side of the Andes, with Viña Indomita’s textured, chocolatey, fragrant example one of the best value wines made from the variety.

Domaine de la Pépière La Pépie Côt, Vin de Pays du Val de Loire, France 2017 (from £13.99, thesmilinggrape.com; lescaves.co.uk)
From a producer “right on the edge of Brittany”, this is malbec grown at its most northerly limits, where south-facing slopes provide enough sun to produce a joyfully brisk and crunchy style with a red berry and currant-scented succulence.

BEST BUY
Matias Riccitelli Hey Malbec, Mendoza, Argentina 2017 (£12.99, or £10.99 as part of a mixed case of six bottles, majestic.co.uk)
Matias Riccitelli is one of the brightest winemaking sparks in Argentina, and here he shows his skill in a classic, accessible style with full-flavoured palate-coating dark fruit and a kiss of cherry-bakewell oak and chocolate. Good value.

Altos Las Hormigas Terroir Malbec, Uco Valley, Mendoza, Argentina 2016 (£15.99, Waitrose)
Led by globetrotting Tuscan wine consultant Alberto Antonini, Altos Las Hormigas has been an important force in the Argentinian malbec revolution, and its wines just get better and better: this is beautifully polished, poised and plush.

Familia Zuccardi Poligonos dell Valle de Uco, Mendoza, Argentina 2016 (£16, Morrisons)
Young buck winemaker Sebastián Zuccardi has built on his father’s legacy to make some of the most elegant and balanced high-altitude malbecs (and other red wines) in Argentina, such as this superbly fine-grained beauty.

webTitle: Giles Yeo: ‘Love your food but don’t eat quite as much of it as you want’

fields.headline: Giles Yeo: ‘Love your food but don’t eat quite as much of it as you want’
fields.standfirst: The obesity expert and author of Gene Eating on fad diets, the magic of miso and why he can’t say no to pork scratchings
fields.trailText: The obesity expert and author of Gene Eating on fad diets, the magic of miso and why he can’t say no to pork scratchings
fields.body:
Dr Giles Yeo arrives for lunch in Cambridge by bike from his research lab at Addenbrooke’s Hospital. In a corner of the Oak bistro he exchanges his clip-clop cycling shoes for a pair of sandals, hangs his fluorescent jacket on a peg, and explains to me the heart monitor that – if he keeps it above a certain daily level – saves him £250 a year on his life insurance. “Their goal and my goal are aligned – neither of us wants them to pay out…” Yeo, 45, is the scientific director of a group studying the effects of genetics on food intake and a pioneer in studies of the cause of obesity. He is, grinning at the prospect of lunch, a somewhat daunting picture of health.

I’m eager to see what he is going to order. His well-timed new book, Gene Eating, debunks much of what we might have taken as read about diet and dieting. It presents the evidence to show that any kind of one-size-fits-all regime is likely to be of little value. He has a gift for describing the science of how our bodies take in calories at different rates and respond radically differently to food groups. Calorie-counting ignores the fundamentals of calorie absorption, and is at best a very rough guide. Much of the trick is to find what works for you.

He scans the menu, aware that I am observing his choices. “I am going for the calves’ liver, because I rarely eat it, and I imagine they do it well here,” he says. “And I will have the lobster bisque to start. I love a bisque.” Are we allowed a glass of wine in the middle of the day, he wonders. He decides we are, and orders a large glass of malbec.

Yeo was born in Singapore and grew up in San Francisco. When he came to Cambridge as a postgraduate, he found the food options “a bit embarrassing”. It’s got better now, he says, not least since this place, a confident neighbourhood French restaurant, opened a decade ago. Still he has been unable to find any decent Chinese food in the city – he has to go to London for that.

When Yeo got into the study of obesity, it wasn’t yet a global growth industry. He started by looking at people with rare genetic disorders, “Kids who literally could not stop eating,” he says – he describes in his book the children who have no off switch to their appetite, and will eat fish fingers from the freezer if left alone.

As he and his fellow researchers began to understand more about how the brain failed to control food intake in extreme cases, they started to see how the disruption of those regular pathways was not unique to severely obese people. There was a spectrum. Yeo left pure genetics and became an accidental neuroscientist. His principal interest is now the genetics of how the brain controls food intake.

In some senses, his work flips thinking about diet on its head. I suggest that as a culture we tend to blame multinationals for delivering hidden fat and sugar to us in ways we find hard to resist – are we wrong in that?

“I think blame is a tricky term,” he says. “Do those companies employ scientists and psychologists who are being paid to make food irresistible to us? Of course, and I think sugary drinks are a particular problem. I just happen to look at potential solutions from the biological perspective.”

Part of this, in very practical terms, is taking steps to keep away from the foods we know we cannot control. “To take a personal, very facetious, example,” Yeo says, “I am not allowed to bring chocolate into the house. I can buy it and have one square, but I will stop at that. If my wife knows there is chocolate around, however, she will eat it all. Now, if there are pork scratchings in the house, for me that is a different story…”

So we have to be honest about what we cannot resist and not have it readily available? I feel compelled to confess my cheese habit.

“Exactly. You want the fat. Now, if the government says in order to solve obesity we are going to tax chocolate, that might work with people like my wife. But it would not work for me and my pork scratchings.”

Yeo tends to lecture without shoes on, which helps his undergraduates remember him, he suggests. “That barefoot guy with no hair, talking about diabetes.” He has the look of a guru, but resists the idea of gurus. He prefers to be directed by the complexities of the science. A bit of his experimentation is on himself. For a recent series of the BBC’s Trust Me, I’m a Doctor on which he is a presenter, he ate vegan for a month. A couple of things happened: he lost about 10lbs and his blood cholesterol levels dropped dramatically.

He believes everyone should at least try it, if only to stop being afraid of eating vegan. With the help of his cycling, Yeo has managed to return to his “vegan weight”. But more importantly he now knows he can eat vegan and cook vegan when he wants. As a result he has reduced his meat intake by about half.

He tends to eat vegan lunches now (the bisque and liver are an exception), because he understands his metabolism better. “I realised if I had a coronation chicken sandwich or something with white bread, I would get very wobbly when I cycled the 14 miles home. But if I had a vegan buddha bowl, I didn’t have the wobbles. That was purely because the buddha bowl takes longer to digest. The white bread carbohydrates would have gone in faster and been used up.”

Was he not tempted to maintain his vegan regime?

He says not. “What I missed the most was eggs. But I should write a book called Magic with Miso, because you realise it is all about finding the umami flavour, that richness you get from a meat stock. If you put a tablespoon of miso into a vegetable casserole, that works…”

Related: The unstoppable rise of veganism: how a fringe movement went mainstream

Older food cultures understood that principle, he suggests, in the way that they spread meat flavours through their cooking, without relying on the protein itself – he recalls a staple of his own growing up, which used the liquor of a poached chicken to flavour rice. Fish soups, like the lobster bisque he relishes would be another example.

The men in Yeo’s family have always cooked. His grandpa taught him how to kill a chicken when he was six. “He thought you should always be able to look into the eyes of the animal that you will eat. That is why the Chinese tend to leave the heads on their duck and fish. It reminds you that provenance matters.”

Yeo is likeably ruthless in his book in demolishing some of the fad diets that have made their “inventors” rich. “The idea that you should eat alkaline – drink pH9 water or whatever – has absolutely no scientific truth,” he says. “The detox diet is the one that actually costs a lot of money though. I hear Gwyneth Paltrow is opening a store on Oxford Street. I’m amazed they allowed her in.”

He is alarmed by the rise of “orthorexia”, the fear of eating badly, which ascribes pious morality to what’s on your plate. “It narrows your diet and, if you break the rule, leads you into that cycle of depression and despair of other eating disorders.”

I ask how much technology will allow us to customise our attempts at weight loss, and if that is a good thing.

By way of answer he explains how, for another self-experiment, he was recently fitted with an internal glucose monitor of the kind that type 1 diabetics use. “I had all this data about the way I respond to food. I was surprised to find white rice gave me the highest sugar spike of anything, but bread not so much. Everyone would be different, with those peaks.” He hasn’t stopped eating white rice, but is more aware of the consequences. He suggests that eventually you might take a picture of your food and an algorithm will tell you the likely effect on your heart rate and your waistline. “More information has to be better,” he insists.

How about new year resolutions, I wonder, before he gets back on his bike. What would he advise?

“Two things: if you want to lose weight you need a diet to suit your particular lifestyle and your weaknesses. The other thing is: never fear food. Love it, but don’t eat quite as much of it as you want.”

Gene Eating is out now (Seven Dials, £14.99). To buy a copy for £13.19, go to theguardianbookshop.com. or call 0330 333 6846. Free UK p&p over £15, online orders only. Phone orders min. p&p of £1.99.
